data.title: First time
data.text: Since this was our 1st visit, we tried three favorites.  Peking duck, Gen Tso chicken & green beans.  We had the beans spiced up and they were the star. G Tso was OK but I missed pineapple and the sauce was sparse.  Lots of garlic which I liked.  Probably won't order again.  The duck was tasty but I missed the crispy skin.  The wrapper was small and thick.  It made it difficult to wrap the ingredients.  I would much prefer the thin rice pancakes.  Service was very good, personable & attentive.  There are many many more dishes to try so could be a "go to" place

data.title: Yes, it is authentic
data.text: Yes, this is really high quality authentic food. But will you really like it?  I did like it for the experience. Seems that every table was filled , but 90 percent seemed to have Chinese ancestry. The prices are too high for me, given that it offers an authentic experience rather than food "to die for".  Favorite dish is double cooked pork. Try the dried green beans.

data.title: Not fancy, very authentic food
data.text:
This restaurant is the most authentic Chinese food we have found in the Triangle.  The restaurant has been filled with native Chinese locals every time we've been there.  It isn't a huge space and certainly isn't fancy or particularly full of ambiance, but it has become a favorite of ours.  

They have a very small selection of dim sum, and a larger menu that is very authentic of appetizers, entrees, noodles, etc.  The flavors are just delicious - I don't really know how to describe them other than flavorful and rich and just the right amount of heat.

The service is very good - friendly and lots of servers around, though you have to work a little with them on the English communication sometimes.

Definitely recommend

data.title: Not Your Typical Chinese Food
data.text: This restaurant has mastered the cooking and the addition  of spices to the dishes to those I can recollect of the dishes in China . Would highly recommend this restaurant vegetarian or otherwise especially if you like spicy and traditional foods

data.title: The menu is large, not the restaurant - with wonderful Chinese food
data.text: Crowded, with many Chinese diners, very pleasant and attentive wait staff rushing around. Many choices on the menu. The food was terrific, the portions ample, the prices reasonable. The noise level was pretty high with lots of people enjoying dinner and it seemed they were all talking at once.

data.title: Excellent as always for vegetarians
data.text: We came back here before taking in a movie across the street at the small city-owned Cary Theater.  This restaurant is a favorite of the local Chinese community.  They have a new menu that does not have all the dishes they can offer.  For example, we did not see hot and sour soup on it, but when we asked, they were quick to provide it.  It was excellent.  We shared the large homestyle tofu with vegetables.  Remembering the last time we had it, we asked them to tone down the scorchingly hot chiles, which they did.  It was very tasty.  Our friend had the lamb with scallions (really mostly white onions).  He enjoyed it.

data.title: Best authentic chinese food
data.text: I come here regularly with my wife or with our chinese visitors and have never been disappointed.  The food is great.  I like the spicy ones, like cumin lamb (with szechuan peppers), beef hot pot stew, garlic green beans, woosie pork and lots more.  This is not your typical american chinese restaurant.  They have "real" chinese menu which can be challenging.  Boiled fish may not sound good, but it is awesome and spicy.  The waiters will try their best to explain the menu.  Try to come early as parking can be a problem.

data.title: Great menu
data.text: Wait staff was very attentive. The menu is extensive with many choices that would not be on the menu at a typical Chinese restaurant, the orange chicken was really tasty and had the right amount of heat. Can't wait to go back to try other things.

data.title: My favorite!
data.text: If you like authentic and spicy style Chinese dishes, this is the place. Szechuan type of food and some of Taiwan. They carry some beers, but I only had Tsingtao.  Many local Chinese families and students frequent there. We usually go there 2-3 times a month. During the weekends, you will have to wait for a table. And service suffers too. But worth it.

data.title: So much better then expected
data.text: My family and I just moved from China to Cary and we have been looking for a good Chinese place. We finally found it at Taipei 101. The food is Szechuan style and is very good. We were the only non Chinese in the place, which is always a good sign. Although the food is still a bit Americanized it was a good find. We will be back.

data.title: service was good
data.text: The waitress came out with the order and said, "you are really going to enjoy this".  I ordered 3 cup chicken.  The chicken was stringy, cut up and full of bones, tough to chew, and was in a nasty heavy brown sauce.  It was served with some whole cloves of garlic which were not cooked or roasted.  Some stringy ugly green vegetable was on the bottom of all this with a few slices of old ginger.  I should have returned it.  The white rice was ok.

data.title: Great Food
data.text: Hard not to order every thing on the menu. If you are not Asian you are the minority at this place.  Had a language barrier with the waitress but she was very nice.  Place is crazy busy and the food is excellent.

data.title: Pretty awful
data.text: We had five entrees and two appetizers. The service was terrible. Multiple dishes that were excessively greasy. Very dirty bathrooms.

data.title: The real deal in Chinese food with a vegetarian options
data.text: We came here before a concert at the Cary Arts Center nearby.  The authenticity of the food is confirmed by the many young Chinese who frequent this restaurant.  We had an unusual dish of Chinese greens in a milky sauce with pieces of what seemed to be ancient and black eggs - the latter not exactly to our taste, but the greens were very good.  We also had the Mapo tofu that was rich is spicy chiles - hot but not overwhelming despite their quantity.  Ample amounts of steamed rice accompanied the dishes.  Prices have gone up a lot since our last visit.  New menu = higher prices!

data.title: Not as expected
data.text: When looking for "good Chinese food" looked on yelp for assistance. Upon arrival, when ordered, took time for food to arrive. If food is top shelf, usually likely to overlook that, but food was lacking flavor, vegetables were soggy and ingredient's didn't taste fresh and no ambience for what is advertised as an authentic Chinese food environment

data.title: Delicious, Authentic Food
data.text: My friend, who knows their Asian cuisine, recommended this place and I’m glad I listened.  This restaurant has some of the most authentic Chinese food in the Triangle.  Initially I was skeptical of this small, unassuming place but the food was a wonderful surprise very economical too.

data.title: Authentic Chinese in Downtown Cary
data.text: This has been our go to place for Chinese since the first time we tried them.  Huge portions, great flavor and service.  Love their Hot & Sour Soup & Kung Pao Chicken.  For those who have a large palate, there are many authentic dishes to be tried.  You know it's good because it is always filled with people of the culture.

data.title: Authentic and fun
data.text:
Went here in a group of 6 and one of the group was a native of China. That helped!

On a Friday night the place was full and almost everyone was Asian. We ended up ordering several appetizers and an entree each and shared everything.

One of the apps was fried "stinky tofu" which is tofu that has fermented. I was prepared for the worst but it wasn't too bad. Overall reaction at our table was mixed. The best app was a combination of pancake and thin beef.

My favorite entree was Salt and Pepper Squid. Strips of squid were covered with a light tempura battered and fried beautifully - light and not greasy! Also quite good was Pork with Lotus Root. The taste was excellent although there was very little pork in the dish. Eggplant with Garlic Sauce was also quite good. 

Less successful were a fish stew with hot peppers. It didn't have much flavor aside from the peppers. We had Stir Fried Lamb with Spicy (sic) which had only one chili icon on the menu but was too hot for my somewhat timid taste.

My least favorite dish was a chicken dish that had the chicken sliced into rounds like silver dollars. There were bits of bone within it and you had to be careful eating it.

The service was quite good and, as is typical in Taiwan, the dishes came out as they were ready, in no particular order.

Other odds and ends - they place looks a bit dumpy from the outside but looks much nicer inside. If you want beer your choice is Tsingtao. And that's it. They looked to have some open wine bottles in a refrigerator case but none of us wanted to try that.

Overall, it was a good experience and I believe that we will return.

data.title: Taipei 101 is world class!
data.text: I stumbled upon Taipei 101 about 2 weeks ago while doing my routine search for good Chinese food in the Cary Area. I have become accustomed to being disappointed whenever I search, but this time to my delight I found my new go to place. Upon entering this restaurant for dinner I was very happy to see that the restaurant was completely filled with customers, (mostly Asian). Let's face it, when I go to a great Italian Restaurant, I want to see  that its filled with Italians, after all, if they like it.... right?? So my expectations and my taste buds were up already. Here's the good news, the food was fantastic. I ordered egg drop soup (which wasnt even on the menu) and I must say, if that is the way the soups is supposed to taste, then I have never really experienced a great egg drop soup before now. It was amazing, as was the Potstickers and the Pecan Shrimp with Broccoli dinner. I highly recommend you try this restaurant for a great tasting authentic dinner. They also serve lunch. Portions are good size, prices pretty reasonable. There are quite a number of unusual items on the menu for the more adventurous types. It appears to be family run. Their brand new menus are beautiful (they tell me that they had them done in China!). Perhaps all restaurants should print their menus there. This one is one you will certainly want to try. Finally, great tasting authentic Chinese cuisine right here in downtown Cary.

data.title: nice place, nice food
data.text: we went there for lunch. the outside doesnt do justice to the interiors. Big place, but still almost completely occupied during a saturday lunch. food is nice. we ordered 3-cut chicken, vegetables in garlic sauce and a couple of other dishes. the flavors might not be for everyone though. the "authentic" part of the description of the restaurant might be true after all.
